title: Fairhead: If BBC Trust continues in current form 'that's fine, if it changes - that's fine' | Media | The Guardian

fairhead : licence fee 'is the most appropriate way to fund ' bbc .

documents.title: summary : supports licence fee , but will consider other options ; if bbc trust continues in current form 'that 's fine , if it changes - that 's fine '
text: ● fairhead said the licence fee is the most appropriate way to fund '' the bbc , a point she reiterated several times , while eventually admitting she would consider other options .

● however , she is more open minded about whether the bbc trust should be replaced with a new regulatory and governance body : if it continues in its current form for me , that 's fine , if it changes - that 's fine . ''

● she sees her role as representing licence fee payers , defending the bbc 's impartiality , establishing a successful working relationship with director general tony hall , and ensuring the bbc responds to radical changes in the broadcasting environment .
● tony hall should be the voice of the bbc '' .
you should expect to see more of the director general as the face of the bbc and i am the face of the trust and governance .
that got a little bit blurred in the past . ''
● fairhead would like to hang on to her non-executive board roles at hsbc and pepsi .
if that is not tenable , my primary role is at the bbc . ''

fairhead is asked , finally , about culture secretary sajid javid 's overnight announcement that the government will conduct a review of whether to decriminalise licence fee evasion before next year 's general election - not after , as the bbc was hoping .
she says she welcomes the debate and the review should absolutely take place '' .

fairhead goes on to make the point the bbc has pushed previously , that 5 % of those who should pay do n't and if all these licence fees were lost it would mean £ 200m a year less to spend on programming .
whatever happens , the bbc should not end up with less money , she adds .
there 's a lot of detail to be worked on and options to be looked at .
with that , whittingdale thanks fairhead for attending and calls time on the session .

fairhead is asked again about her view on the licence fee and says that her strong opinion going into the job and charter review is that there are some very strong benefits '' , but says she is open to looking at other options .
fairhead is asked about bbc worldwide , the corporation 's commercial arm , and its lonely planet acquisition ( and subsequent big loss making sale ) .
to my mind , i thought that was a wrong decision because , my sense was it was a perfectly well functioning commercial market which did n't need bbc as an element of it , '' she replies .
john plunkett ( @ johnplunkett149 ) rona fairhead key words of today 's exchanges with mps : openness , trust , processes .
jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) immediately goes on to say as long as `` programming quality is not jeopardised by what we do ''
jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) asked about diversity at the bbc fairhead says things are going right way esp re # women on screen but more needs to be done
fairhead : the bbc has to have a relentless '' commitment to improving diversity but you also have to keep in mind the programming quality is not jeopardised by whatever you do '' .
she adds that the bbc is heading in the right direction on diversity , but it 's not perfect , that is absolutely clear '' .
fairhead says she met hall before she was made the government 's preferred candidate , would not have gone for the job if she had n't because chemistry '' is all important .
had 90-minute meeting .
i thought we were people who thought we could work with [ each other ] . ''
she has not met him since but has spoken to him on the phone .
jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) fairhead has met tony hall once and has spoken to him on the phone once since her candidacy announced

text: john plunkett ( @ johnplunkett149 ) rona fairhead : licence fee 'is the most appropriate way to fund ' bbc
fairhead is asked about what she expects her relationship with bbc director general tony hall to be .
i think it 's important the voice of the bbc should be the director general , he is the one who is running the bbc , '' she replies .
you should expect to see more of the director general as the face of the bbc and i am the face of the trust and governance .
that got a little bit blurred in the past . ''
this appears to give credence to the theory that fairhead could take more of a background role , leaving hall to take the lead in making the case for bbc charter and licence fee renewal .
we shall see .
fairhead on the £ 100m dmi fiasco : i would like to say i have never been involved in any company that has had any waste in its digital investment but it 's a tough thing to get right .
that said it was a very significant amount of money to write off .
it was a brave decision , the right decision , to stop throwing good money after bad .
what it highlighted was the project really was n't managed as well as it could be . ''
again , a diplomatic response .

documents.title: fairhead : licence fee has 'some very , very significant benefits '
text: however , on the other key question - the licence fee - fairhead appears to back the status quo : i think there are some very , very significant benefits of the licence fee .
it ensures independence , a universal service for a universal fee that is very important and ensures creative freedom . ''

documents.title: fairhead : if bbc trust continues in current form 'that 's fine , if it changes - that 's fine '
text: ok , now we get the guts of the whole hearing : does fairhead see her role as to help abolish her job , bradshaw asks .
ie does she support the bbc trust in its existing form ?
fairhead says she sees her job as representing licence fee payers and making sure the bbc 's governance and regulatory structure is the best for the future '' .
this is a critical part [ of my job ] .
my view is that you work on the principles and if that means there is n't a role for me at that time , then so be it . ''
she adds that she would be very surprised '' if the bbc trust remained unchanged following charter renewal in 2016 .
this to my mind is not a 20-year job . ''

pressed on whether she would defend the existing bbc trust structure , she replies : my role is to help this structure be as effective as it could possibly be build a governance structure that i think is fit for purpose and that 's my position . ''

on whether she would be interested in being chair of unitary bbc board that might replace the current bbc trust , she says : that is a relatively hypothetical question , i would rather focus on the job in hand . ''
as for the bbc trust , fairhead adds : if it continues in its current form for me , that 's fine , if it changes - that 's fine . ''
this is a very significant exchange - we appear to have a bbc trust chair who 's not particularly wedded to the current system of governance and regulation .

documents.title: role at hsbc
text: another potentially tricky question , as fairhead 's asked about her role at hsbc .
we came through the financial crisis much more strongly and much more resiliently than others .
one has to be realistic - sometimes bad things do happen and controls you think are effective turn out not to be so .
it 's about how you respond .

the only way to respond if you have made a mistake , firstly you apologise and then you are very thorough in an investigation of what has gone wrong and money is no object in fixing that and having systems in place [ to ensure ] as far as possible it will not happen again . ''
you suspect fairhead 's hsbc experience , while potentially tricky in relation to the bbc job , will also come in handy when the next crisis blows up .
asked about her role in tax avoidance schemes at pearson : it 's appropriate for corporations and people to pay tax according to both the spirit and the letter of the law .
that is what i have always done make sure i paid all that tax that i need to . ''

on pearson tax avoidance : the structure which was criticised at pearson was very standard at the time we were trying to invest in new programmes , it was a mechanism to enhance tax deductibility particularly in the us .
that has all been swept away ``
the guardian 's charlotte higgins , author of an impressive recent series of essays on the past , present and future of the bbc , is also watching the hearing .
she tweets : charlotte higgins ( @ chiggi ) i would n't count myself as an establishment figure , says cabinet office board member rona fairhead .
davies asks , is she an establishment figure who wo n't rock the boat ?
i would n't count myself as an establishment figure .
i am independent of mind and view and i am very clear that my primary role is to represent the audience . ''
fairhead adds that she would rather not sell her remaining pearson shares , but will do if continuing to hold them brings my integrity into account '' - a similar reply to the hsbc board question .
davies says she ca n't ride two horses '' .
fairhead is asked by davies about her £ 1.1m payoff from pearson , so we 're stepping into executive payoffs , a particularly tricky question for the bbc .
after a little to and fro , fairhead says : i am not going to apologise for the fact that i came from the private sector .
but when you are in the publicly-funded world , you have to look at costs through a different lens . ''
fairhead is asked about her thoughts on the future of the bbc .
she responds that it would be wrong for me to have a definitive vision of the bbc right now '' .
okaaaay .
the prospective bbc trust chair is showing some political nous here , straight batting potentially tough questions .
earlier fairhead dodged an attempt by davies to get her to pass judgment on patten 's ill-starred tenure .
she declined to be drawn .
john plunkett ( @ johnplunkett149 ) fairhead on lack b'casting exp : 'sometimes it helps you can ask the really stupid questions and sometimes they do n't have answer '

documents.title: thoughts on licence fee
text: another key question - what does she think of the licence fee ?
there is a lot of sense having it focused on the bbc because of clarity and accountability , '' fairhead replies .
not quite completely resounding , but pretty clear none the less .
now , one of the key questions , from former culture secretary ben bradshaw : what bbc output does she consume ?
fairhead says she wakes up to the today programme and goes to bed with the 10 o'clock news or bbc news channel .
so far , so reading from the bbc script .

but then something more personal - she recalls how as a child the family sat down on saturday evenings to have supper together and watch doctor who , and then she went to bed but was allowed to get up for match of the day .
now rona 's on a roll , reeling off current bbc hits : sherlock a massive favourite '' with her family , she enjoyed the honourable woman , watches our zoo .
apparently some members of her family love great british bake off '' - she wo n't embarrass them by saying who ( watching gbbo is socially embarrassing ?
tell that to the 8 million plus who watch ! ) .
sport ( tricky one , how to avoid mentioning sky ?
) : wimbledon , six nations ( nicely done , all bbc ) .
natural history - we 've got all the attenborough box sets i think brian cox is fantastic ``
fairhead says she immediately stepped down from various civil service projects she was involved in when she was offered the bbc job .
however , she adds that if the bbc trust job is genuinely three days work a week - as advertised - she can keep her non-exec directorships at hsbc and pepsi .
if that is not tenable , my primary role is at the bbc . ''
you suspect fairhead may find like her predecessors that the bbc role is all-consuming , despite its non-executive nature .

documents.title: political affiliations
text: fairhead is asked about her political affiliations .
i have never in my life been politically active . ''
responding to questions about her partner , a former tory councillor : it 's not my husband who 's applying for this role , it 's myself . ''

documents.title: relationship with george osborne
text: responding to reports about how well she knows george osborne , fairhead says she has met the chancellor at formal functions and across room at parents meetings '' , as their children attend the same school .
i am not on close personal terms with the chancellor . ''
my colleague john plunkett is also tweeting on the hearing : john plunkett ( @ johnplunkett149 ) rona fairhead : i did not discuss my application with anyone in govt .
was keen to keep number people who knew about it very small

my colleague jane martinson , who is at the hearing , tweets : jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) no i do n't think gender is important she replies with the grace of someone just accused of enjoying special favours
tory mp philip davies , who delighted in niggling fairhead 's predecessor lord patten at committee hearings , with entertainingly ill-tempered results , is now asking questions .
is the bbc impartial ?
broadly i think it is , '' fairhead responds .
davies mentions reports that david cameron wanted to have a woman in the bbc trust chair role for the first time .
fairhead confirms that she 's a woman .
is gender important to the trust role ?
no , it should be the person who has skills for role . ''
committee chair john whittingdale opens with a tester : why do you want the job ? ''
fairhead talks about how the bbc is a vitally important institution in the uk .
despite some recent problems , it remains one of the most loved institutions in the uk .
it has a critical role in the uk creative sector helps us establish our place in the world .
for many people here and around the world , it represents the best of british . ''
she adds that she wants to help build a future for the bbc in which people are proud to work for it and it has the full confidence of licence fee payers .
sets out four key principles : 1 .
i would see my role as chair of the trust to be above all things the representative of the audience , of licence fee payers . ''
i will defend vigorously , against all comers , the impartiality of the bbc .
this is a critical point , we lose that at our peril as a country and organisation . ''
i will respect the different roles of the [ bbc ] executive and trust .
i will work with the director general [ tony hall ] to address issues flagged very publicly and openly '' recently .
recognises there are questions hanging over bbc on trust and value for money .
aware a lot of work has been undertaken by hall and his team to address these issues .
moving in the right direction - fairhead sees her role as to take this further .
make sure the bbc responds to changes in its environment '' , which are radical .
fairhead mentions factors including an explosion of choice '' for listeners and viewers , and the emergence of new and very large media conglomerates '' .
you can watch live streaming of the hearing via parliament live tv

speaking of the licence fee , conservative culture secretary sajid javid has lobbed a timely grenade for the bbc to juggle , with overnight briefings to the media revealing that his rts london conference speech on tuesday afternoon will include the announcement of a government review of whether non-payment should be decriminalised .
the review , which was already part of a deregulation bill that gained cross-party support earlier this year , is being brought forward .

as my colleagues chris johnston and jane martinson wrote : javid will tell the rts that almost 200,000 people were prosecuted in 2012-13 for failing to buy a tv licence , which costs £ 145.50 a year .
more than 50 were sent to prison .
when over 10 % of magistrates court cases concern this one offence , you have to ask whether the current system is really working .
so that 's exactly what i 'm going to do , '' he is expected to say .
the government plans to review decriminalisation once the deregulation bill receives royal assent .
however , the culture secretary will say that the process needs to begin immediately .
very shortly i will be publishing the terms of reference for a review of tv licence enforcement .
i expect it to begin taking evidence in the autumn , and to conclude early in the next parliament , '' he will tell the society .
i do n't want to pre-empt the [ bbc ] charter review .
i want to ensure that , when it begins , it has a solid evidence base on which to draw .
this will allow it to shape the future of the bbc in a way that works for both the corporation and those who pay for it . ''
decriminalisation has been backed by the conservative and labour parties , although the deputy prime minister , nick clegg , has struck a cautious note about the move .
he has highlighted bbc concerns that any move to encourage licence fee evasion could reduce the broadcaster 's income and lead to services being cut .
good morning .
rona who ?
relatively little is known about rona fairhead , the government 's preferred candidate to replace lord patten as bbc trust chair .

arguably that makes tuesday morning 's pre-appointment hearing before mps on the culture , media and sport select committee , chaired by john whittingdale , a far more important event than the one patten attended four years ago .
after all , what new were we going to learn about the tory grandee after three decades in public life ?
fairhead is a former ft chief executive and pearson finance director who now serves on the boards of hsbc and pepsi .
so plenty of city experience , but no broadcasting work on her cv .

we also know nothing about fairhead 's views on the licence fee , whether she thinks the bbc trust she is about to take charge of should continue or be abolished , as many external critics believe , or whether she 's an archers or eastenders fan .
perhaps most pertinently to tuesday 's televised grilling before mps , fairhead has relatively little experience as a public speaker , or the public face of a large organisation .
how will she stand up to the scrutiny ?
the hearing begins at 10.30am .
